sources.full: Arcanum Worlds; Odyssey of the Dragonlords

monster.name: Marble Golem
languages: speaks the languages of its creator (usually common)

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: 傀儡对任何会改变其形态的法术或效果都是免疫的。

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: 傀儡在对抗法术和其他魔法效果时有优势。

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: 傀儡的武器攻击是有魔法的。

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: 当大理石雕像保持不动，它与普通雕像没有区别。

trait.name: Relentless
entries: 当命中率降至0时，巨魔会停止所有行动，但它不会死亡。在下一回合结束时，巨魔会重新获得一半的命中率。
这被认为是其新的最大命中率总量。这只能被触发两次。每当relentelss被触发时，巨魔会获得一个随机的残疾（（%0%））。
1. 断矛。巨魔只能使用猛击攻击。
2. 断臂。巨魔只能使用一次长矛攻击。
3. 断腿。傀儡的移动距离减少到5英尺。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 傀儡会进行两次长矛或猛击攻击。

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4})重击伤害。

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4})重击伤害。
大理石雕像通常被雕刻成过去的美丽英雄和统治者的样子。建造它们的巫师需要伟大的工匠的服务，因为石像的特征必须非常逼真，才能使动画的魔法生效。有传言说，邪恶的巫师为了得到他们所需的建筑材料，不惜将美丽的年轻人石化。
审美守护者。大理石雕像通常被设置在需要审美的地方--寺庙、宫殿、图书馆或庄园。大理石雕像可以伪装成普通的雕像，但在某些情况下它们会活过来。例如，它可能会攻击那些没有说出适当密码就进入房间的闯入者。它们也可以在其指定的主人的命令词下激活。
自恋的精神。大理石雕像是由从元素界挖来的灵魂激活的，并被强行捆绑在人造身体上。不知不觉中被吸引到这些特殊构造中的灵魂总是虚荣的，而巨石像的建造者在编织必要的束缚咒语时利用了他们自负的天性。只要精神发现它的新形式和周围环境适当地美丽，它就不太可能挣脱其主人的控制。因此，人们非常注意确保大理石雕像的展示方式，以强调和尊重它们的美。
无情的追击。大理石雕像通常会在敌人逃跑后停止攻击。然而，如果大理石雕像的美貌被破坏了，里面的灵魂就会被激怒。大理石魔像将变得无情地追踪并杀死破坏它的人。虽然石像没有任何追踪其仇恨对象的魔法能力，但它可以追踪脚印，而且它会审问（或摧毁）任何挡在它面前的人。

trait.name: Charge
entries: 如果半人马向目标直行至少30英尺，然后在同一回合用长矛攻击击中目标，目标会受到额外的10（（%0%））穿刺伤害。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 半人马进行两次攻击：一次用长矛，一次用蹄子，或两次用长弓。

action.name: Jancan Pike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 6})砍击伤害。

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7}击中，范围150/600英尺，一个目标。{@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4})穿刺伤害。
半人马傲慢、虚荣，对自己的亲属非常忠诚，是一种上半身是人、下半身是马的生物。他们聚集成游牧部落，在开阔的土地上游荡，白天进行短兵相接，晚上在星空下歌唱。
半人马的文化非常强调武艺，他们通常被期望在足够大的年龄拿起武器时就磨练他们的战斗技巧。半人马喜欢长弓和杆状武器，后者使他们在与较小的种族作战时能够利用其庞大的体型。尽管半人马专注于战争，但他们是一个有高度文化的民族，产生了令人印象深刻的艺术和歌曲作品，尽管这些作品很少与外人分享。
自然德鲁伊。半人马觉得自己与自然有特殊的联系，并对任何不尊重自然的人进行报复。在半人马中，德鲁伊艺术的先天资质是很常见的。年轻的半人马小马驹如果表现出法术天赋，很快就会被识别出来，并在很小的时候就被训练成德鲁伊。半人马德鲁伊在他们的同龄人中受到高度尊重，因为他们与土地和星星的联系比大多数种族更深。
自由奔放的游牧者。半人马不建立永久的定居点，而是不断地漫游，在狩猎条件好的地方建立新的临时营地。他们仰望星空，以确定什么时候该搬到新的牧场。半人马以猎物和偶尔的觅食为生，发现农业的概念非常奇怪。这种做法需要扎根于一个地方，而且他们认为驯化动物是对自然的完全颠倒。
半人马在Thylea
半人马对Thylea的本土神灵有着强烈的忠诚。大多数部落敬仰Thylea母神，但也有许多部落崇拜双子泰坦，Sydon和Lutheria。这并不一定使他们变得邪恶--泰坦长期以来一直保护着半人马部落，并以光荣的战斗和丰饶的土地保佑他们。
半人马的历史可以追溯到定居者种族到来之前很久。当第一批定居者到达时，半人马部落对他们的存在基本无动于衷。但在第一次战争中，龙王和五神对半人马部落进行了毁灭性的打击。这导致了长期的敌意。因此，在过去的几个世纪里，半人马越来越多地试图通过任何必要的手段将入侵的定居种族赶出蒂勒亚。

trait.name: Charge
entries: 如果半人马德鲁伊向一个目标直线移动至少30英尺，然后在同一回合用长矛攻击击中该目标，该目标会受到额外的10（（%0%））穿刺伤害。

trait.name: Wildshape
entries: 每天两次，半人马德鲁伊可以使用一个额外的动作来改变成一个巨大的蝎子、虎鲸或巨鹰。半人马德鲁伊的统计数据会被野兽的统计数据所取代，但德鲁伊会保留自己的方向、性格、智力、智慧和魅力分数。当半人马德鲁伊变身时，它将拥有野兽的命中率和命中骰子。当半人马德鲁伊恢复到它的正常形态时，它将恢复到变身前的命中率。然而，如果半人马德鲁伊是由于命中率下降到0而恢复的，任何多余的伤害都会延续到正常形态。在野兽形态下，半人马德鲁伊不能施放法术，但这并不影响它对已经施放的法术的专注。
法术攻击。半人马德鲁伊是一个9级的施法者。它的法术能力是智慧（法术救赎（%0%），用法术攻击命中率（%1%））。它有以下德鲁伊法术的准备。
咒语（随意）：德鲁伊之术、产生火焰、抵抗力、希勒拉赫
一级 (4个槽): 纠缠, 治疗词, 长骑兵, 与动物对话, 雷电波
第二层（3个槽）：动物信使、野皮、热金属
第三级（3个槽）：召唤闪电，植物生长
第四级（1个插槽）：控水，火墙
5级(1个槽): 树形步法

action.name: Change Shape
entries: 半人马德鲁伊可以在采取常规行动之前或之后使用它的野性形态作为一个额外的行动。半人马在它的新形态中保留改变形态的动作。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 半人马德鲁伊进行两次攻击：一次用长矛，一次用蹄子。

action.name: Pike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达10英尺，一个目标。{@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4})重击伤害。

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: 如果半人马领主的拯救动作失败，它可以选择成功。

trait.name: Charge
entries: 如果半人马向一个目标直线移动至少30英尺，然后在同一回合用长矛攻击击中它，目标会受到额外的20（（%0%））穿刺伤害。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 半人马进行四次攻击：三次用风暴矛，一次用蹄子，或四次用长弓。

action.name: Storm Pike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}12 ({@damage 1d10 + 7})砍击伤害加上10 ({@damage 3d6})闪电伤害。

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9}击中，范围150/600英尺，一个目标。{@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Blessing of the Gods
entries: 作为一个额外的动作，半人马领主呼唤众神。方圆30英尺内的所有半人马，包括半人马领主，都能获得祝福咒语的好处，持续1分钟。半人马领主不需要专注于这个法术。

trait.name: Poor Depth Perception
entries: 在对超过30英尺以外的目标进行任何攻击时，blemys都处于不利地位。

trait.name: Fury
entries: 随着战斗的进行，漂移者变得更加愤怒。
一旦blemys受到伤害，它就会变得愤怒，并获得2点力量（以及（%0%）命中和所有攻击的伤害）。在blemys的每个回合开始时，它的力量会再增加2，最多30。
随着怒气的增加，漂移者还会得到其他的奖励。

trait.name: Round 2
entries: 对所有的攻击都有优势。

trait.name: Round 3
entries: 可以使用一个额外动作来冲刺。

trait.name: Round 4
entries: 抵抗重击、穿刺和砍击伤害。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 漂移者会进行两次抓取攻击。它每拥有一个生物就可以进行一次砸击或投掷攻击（%0%）。

action.name: Grab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}13 ({@damage 3d4 + 6})重击伤害。目标是{@condition grappled}（逃跑{@dc 16}）。如果目标是大的或小的，那么也是{@condition restrained}直到抓取结束。
漂泊者在同一时间可以有两个目标（%0%）。

action.name: Smash
entries: 漂泊者将其拥有的一个大型或小型生物（%0%）反复砸向地面，造成19（{@damage 3d8 + 6}）重击伤害。

action.name: Throw
entries: 漂泊者投掷它所拥有的一个大型或小型生物（%0%）。被投掷的生物需要16（（%1%）+
6) 冲击性伤害。漂泊者可以将抛出的生物瞄准它周围60英尺内的另一个目标生物。
它以{@hit 9}的速度进行攻击，如果成功，两个生物都受到16({@damage 4d4 + 6})的重击伤害。
独眼巨人是一个原始的巨人种族，是神的后代。他们的古老祖先是伟大的士兵、铁匠和建筑工人。今天，大多数独眼巨人只是他们祖先的一个苍白的反映。他们的体型、智力、手臂或手指的数量都会有所不同，但有一个特征总是相同的--眉毛下有一只大眼睛，而不是两只。
来自神的后裔。独眼巨人的血管里流着神的血液。帝王是独眼巨人最常见的祖先，尽管有些独眼巨人可以声称是在遥远的过去拜访过凡人世界的小神的孩子。
失去的目的。剑水蚤曾经有一个更大的目的--锻造供神使用的武器；看守装满末日武器的巨大宝库；或者建造巨大的堡垒、塔楼和其他奇妙的建筑。这些伟大的任务早已被放弃或遗忘。
痴情。独眼巨人经常迷恋精灵种族的成员。这种迷恋注定会以悲剧收场，因为费族人认为独眼巨人是丑陋的畜生。独眼巨人最好的希望是成为一个仆人，被利用和操纵。
武器和盔甲。大多数独眼巨人穿着不合身的衣服和野蛮的武器，但也有一些人比较幸运。这些独眼巨人穿着由强大的赞助人提供的精心制作的武器和盔甲。
装备精良的独眼巨人
一个拥有强大守护者的独眼巨人穿着夹板衣、盾牌和战锤。这些独眼巨人有19点攻击力。特别强大的独眼巨人可能会挥舞着大锤，每次攻击都会造成29（6d6+8）的重击伤害。
勃莱米斯
Blemys是没有头的独眼龙。相反，他们有一只巨大的独眼，以及一个鼻子和一个嘴巴，在他们的胸部中央。布莱米人是被诅咒的独眼巨人，他们独自生活，充满了愤怒和怨恨。他们沸腾的怒火常常在战斗中沸腾起来，使他们成为更可怕的敌人。

需要证明的东西。尽管漂泊者的外表几乎是滑稽的，但他们是可怕的敌人。低估它们的能力会导致它们的不幸死亡。一个没有从弱小生物那里得到应有的和适当的尊重的blemys，会通过把这些不尊重的敌人撕碎来显示其巨大的力量。由于没有头颅，人们经常认为斑纹鱼没有智慧，许多非斑纹鱼的人错误地认为它们真的没有大脑。事实上，blemys是剑水蚤中最聪明的类型。它们可以智取一般的凡人定居者，就像它们在过去的年代里智取它们的文明表亲--吉甘人一样。避免与blemys发生冲突的最佳策略是向它挑战，进行一场智慧的较量。让blemys赢，然后求饶，可能会让它受宠若惊，从而饶过失败者的性命。如果漂泊者被明显具有优势的智力击败，它的羞辱很可能会促使它在愤怒中进行攻击。在这种情况下，对手可以利用blemys的有限视野。如果一个灵巧的、善于观察的人躲避出血虫的极端隧道视野足够长的时间，那么它可能会相信它的猎物已经逃脱，并在流泪的沮丧中放弃搜寻。
游牧的生活方式。Blemys的多刺性格和反社会倾向使这些生物无法形成社区。它们靠袭击防御薄弱的定居点获取食物和其他物品为生，如果有机会，它们甚至可能偷窃自己的同类。因此，漂泊者经常发现自己在独自徘徊，因为一旦袭击的幸存者恢复并组织起来，他们很快就会被赶出一个地区。
不确定的起源。这些怪异的独眼巨人的起源不详。一些学者认为，他们的状况是一种神圣的诅咒。Blemys的祖先可能是由一群特别聪明、有魅力、善于交际的独眼巨人组成的文明，他们一反常态地容易产生虚荣心。这可能与大多数独眼巨人的非宗教性质相结合，吸引了残忍的神的注意，他们决定惩罚他们的骄傲和自恋。由于被剥夺了俊美的外表和富裕的生活，漂泊者的文明很快就崩溃了，使他们的后代陷入了永远不满足的孤独生活。

trait.name: Poor Depth Perception
entries: 在对超过30英尺以外的目标进行任何攻击时，吉根人都处于劣势。

trait.name: Six Arms
entries: 吉根人得到一个额外的反应，只能用于机会攻击。

trait.name: Two Shields
entries: 吉根人携带两面盾牌。两者都计入他的装甲等级计算。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 吉根人可以进行三次攻击：一次用抓斗，两次用长矛或两次用标枪。

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Grapple
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。目标是{@condition grappled}（逃跑{@dc 15}）。如果目标是中等或更小，它也是{@condition restrained}，直到抓捕结束。在抓捕目标时，吉根人对目标的攻击卷有优势，不能对其他目标使用此攻击。

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7}击中，范围30/90英尺，一个目标。{@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5})穿刺伤害。
吉冈人是六臂巨人，只有一只眼睛。据传，他们是一个古老的独眼巨人种族的后裔，这个种族是由诸神催生的，在几千年前就已经繁荣起来了。他们的城邦文明以拳击和摔跤为重点，在伟大的游戏竞赛中竞争。有时这些游戏可能会演变成彻底的战争。随着他们曾经的伟大文明的衰落，吉普赛人现在以小型家庭团体的形式生活在一起，有时也独自生活。

文明的。与典型的独眼巨人不同，吉普赛人在他们目前的生活中呼应他们曾经的伟大文明。今天的吉普赛人不是由一个单一的大都市和周边地区组成的城邦，而是以一个强大的家族为基础形成群体。一个gygan社区开始于一个宏伟的创始人家族庄园，随着时间的推移，它吸引了孤独的gygan人和来自其他家族团体的伴侣。这些新来者在附近建造自己的家园，在庄园之间创造了一些相对安全的农田。这些家族群体中的吉普赛人合作生产食物、酒、服装、艺术和娱乐。这些自我维持的社区很少与非吉普赛人交流。因此，每个孤立的家庭团体发展出一种独特的文化，如果灾难降临到社区，可能会完全丧失。一些吉甘家族群体已经变得如此孤立，以至于他们的成员所讲的方言无法被其他讲巨人或普通话的人所理解，包括同一地区的其他吉甘人。
超强的运动员。吉根人的六条手臂使其具有无与伦比的运动能力。他们将力量与敏捷结合起来，由于他们有能力使用多种武器和盾牌，所以是可怕的战士。他们还可以用额外的手臂抓住对手，以便在干掉他们之前将其摁倒。

trait.name: Poor Depth Perception
entries: 在对超过30英尺以外的目标进行任何攻击时，吉根人都处于劣势。

trait.name: Six Arms
entries: 吉根人得到一个额外的反应，只能用于机会攻击。

trait.name: Two Shields
entries: 吉根人携带两面盾牌。两者都计入他的装甲等级计算。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: gygan人进行五次攻击：一次用抓斗，四次用短剑，或者gygan人用标枪进行三次攻击。

action.name: Jancan Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7})穿刺伤害。

action.name: Grapple
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。目标是{@condition grappled}（逃跑{@dc 17}）。如果目标是中等或更小，它也是{@condition restrained}，直到抓捕结束。在抓捕目标时，吉根人对目标的攻击卷有优势，不能对其他目标使用此攻击。

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9}击中，范围30/90英尺，一个目标。{@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6})穿刺伤害。
独眼巨人是一个原始的巨人种族，是神的后代。他们的古老祖先是伟大的士兵、铁匠和建筑工人。今天，大多数独眼巨人只是他们祖先的一个苍白的反映。他们的体型、智力、手臂或手指的数量都会有所不同，但有一个特征总是相同的--眉毛下有一只大眼睛，而不是两只。
来自神的后裔。独眼巨人的血管里流着神的血液。帝王是独眼巨人最常见的祖先，尽管有些独眼巨人可以声称是在遥远的过去拜访过凡人世界的小神的孩子。
失去的目的。剑水蚤曾经有一个更大的目的--锻造供神使用的武器；看守装满末日武器的巨大宝库；或者建造巨大的堡垒、塔楼和其他奇妙的建筑。这些伟大的任务早已被放弃或遗忘。
痴情。独眼巨人经常迷恋精灵种族的成员。这种迷恋注定会以悲剧收场，因为费族人认为独眼巨人是丑陋的畜生。独眼巨人最好的希望是成为一个仆人，被利用和操纵。
武器和盔甲。大多数独眼巨人穿着不合身的衣服和野蛮的武器，但也有一些人比较幸运。这些独眼巨人穿着由强大的赞助人提供的精心制作的武器和盔甲。
装备精良的独眼巨人
一个拥有强大守护者的独眼巨人穿着夹板衣、盾牌和战锤。这些独眼巨人有19点攻击力。特别强大的独眼巨人可能会挥舞着大锤，每次攻击都会造成29（6d6+8）的重击伤害。
詹肯独眼巨人
偶尔，独眼巨人会生下孩子，每只手有十个手指，每只脚有十个脚趾。这些独眼巨人被称为Jancan，他们受到了极大的尊重，因为他们具有非凡的先天才能，可以成为传奇的铁匠。
脾气暴躁。众所周知，詹康人脾气暴躁，性情恶劣。虽然他们可能会忠实地服务于其他圆柱体，但他们经常会对自己的亲属玩弄恶作剧。他们憎恨自己为愚蠢的畜生制作精良武器所花费的漫长岁月。
传说中的铁匠。由于他们多指的手很灵活，詹肯有能力制造奇妙的武器。他们只能为巨大的生物锻造这些物品。这些质量为+1、+2或+3的物品与一个主人的灵魂结合在一起，当主人死亡时，它们就会失去其魔法属性。
被诅咒的武器。由于詹肯人的恶毒性格，他们经常在物品中加入诅咒。有时这可能是一个狂暴的诅咒，有时可能是一个背信弃义的诅咒。
变体独眼巨人 独眼巨人之父
由Jancan装备的强大的独眼巨人领主穿着+2的夹板甲。他们还使用一个+2的盾牌和一个+2的战锤。他们的攻击力为23，命中率为+11，他们的攻击造成21（3d8+11）重击伤害。

monster.name: Bronze Automaton
languages: speaks the languages of its creator (usually common)

trait.name: Death Throes
entries: 当青铜机器人死亡时，有50%的几率会在火灾和闪电的大火中爆炸。在它5英尺范围内的每个生物都必须做一个{@dc 15}灵巧的蓄力动作，蓄力失败会受到17({@damage 5d6})的火焰伤害和17({@damage 5d6})的闪电伤害，蓄力成功则受到一半的伤害。

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: 青铜自动机对任何会改变其形态的法术或效果都是免疫的。

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: 青铜自动机在对法术和其他魔法效果的救赎上有优势。

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: 青铜自动机的武器攻击是神奇的。

trait.name: Martial Advantage
entries: 每回合一次，青铜自动机可以对它用武器攻击击中的生物造成额外的10（（%0%））伤害，如果该生物在青铜自动机的盟友5英尺以内，而该盟友不是（%1%）。

action.name: Multiattack
entries: 青铜自动机进行了两次眩晕攻击。

action.name: Glaive
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6}击中，到达10英尺，一个目标。{@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 3})砍击伤害。
青铜自动机是使用诸神传下来的机械和魔法技术建造的。它们是为战争而建造的，除此之外没有其他用途。它们需要不断的修理和维护，否则就会开始崩溃。这意味着它们作为无人看管的守护者不能超过数年时间。
构建的自然。青铜自动机是终极战士。他们不会衰老，也不需要空气、食物、饮料或睡眠。它们被建造的唯一目的是战斗，直到它们被摧毁。
爆炸性的力量。青铜自动机是由元素火和瓶装闪电的混合物驱动的。当自动机被摧毁时，这种元素能量的混合物可以在自动机的死亡阵痛中释放出来，给站在它们附近的人带来灾难性的结果。幸运的是，青铜自动机对闪电有免疫力，对火有抵抗力，否则这些爆炸可能会导致连锁反应，可能会使整个自动机军团毁灭。

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Keledone对任何会改变其形态的法术或效果都是免疫的。

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Keledone在对抗法术和其他魔法效果时有优势。

action.name: Song of Pain
entries: 凯利多唱起了绝望之歌。在她周围20英尺范围内的每个生物，如果能听到她的声音，并且不是构筑物，就必须成功地进行一次{@dc 14}智慧救赎，如果救赎失败，就会受到28({@damage 8d6})的精神伤害，如果成功，就会受到一半的伤害。

action.name: Song of Sleep
entries: 凯利多唱着歌哄它的敌人入睡。在她20英尺范围内的每个生物，如果能听到她的声音，并且不是构筑物，就必须成功地进行一次{@dc 14}智慧救赎。拯救失败后，该生物会在一分钟内倒下（1%）（或直到它受到伤害或其他生物采取行动将其摇醒）。
Keledone是由众神塑造的金色建筑，类似于拥有巨大闪亮翅膀的美丽女性。这些自动装置以坚定不移的忠诚服务于它们的创造者，有时甚至在它们的创造者被毁灭后也不例外。一些凡人可能会把凯利多恩误认为是女神本人，因为他们的形态完美，而且永恒不变。Keledone倾向于拥有宁静的性格。即使是最可怕的威胁，他们也毫不畏惧。

迷人的旋律。凯莱通最伟大的武器是她宏亮的声音，它有能力唤起所有听到它的人的舒缓安慰和萦绕的绝望。她的一首歌曲挖出并强化了听众最悲伤的记忆，这可能会打破那些意志力较弱的人的心理。另一首曲子则让凯利多的侵略者陷入深深的睡眠。根据受害者犯罪的严重程度，Keledone可能会继续她的昏睡之歌，直到她的目标因脱水而死亡。然而，Keledone不仅将其歌曲用于攻击性目的；它们还被认为可以让陷入困境的凡人祈求者的心灵得到平静和安宁。

天体守护者。Keledone通常负责保护圣地，如寺庙、墓地和其他对其创造者很重要的地点。有些人甚至被建造在他们所负责的墙壁上。与较小的自动装置不同，Keledone不需要维护就能继续执行它们的任务。许多Keledone已经站了几千年了，完全没有被时间所影响。一个Keledone可能被指示使用致命的武力来阻止入侵者，而其他的Keledone则只是确保他们指控的安全。有些Keledone的任务是测试冒险者，确保只有强大的人能够继续前进，找到他们所寻求的知识或宝藏。

机械意志。keledone是被灌输了自我意识的智能构造，这在自动机中是很罕见的。虽然这不是一个固有的特征，但在几个世纪的时间里，Keledone可能会发展出独特的个性或身份。这种现象最常发生在那些经常与其他生命互动的keledone身上，无论他们是其他智能构造物、超自然生物，还是普通人。尽管他们有自己的个性，然而，Keledone推卸责任或放弃她的职位是非常罕见的。那些人发现支撑他们的魔法会开始消退。一个不忠诚的Keledone很快就会失去她的飞行能力，因为她沉重的金属翅膀已经无法支撑她纯金框架的重量。

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: 帝王的先天法术能力是魅力（法术保存（%0%），法术攻击命中率（%1%））。它可以从它的神域中先天性地施放法术，不需要任何物质成分。帝释天只能使用以下法术。

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: 如果帝释天的拯救动作失败，它可以选择成功。

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: 帝释天对法术和其他魔法效果的救赎有优势。

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: 帝王的武器攻击是神奇的。

action.name: Sacred Weapon
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15}击中，到达10英尺，一个目标。{@h}23 ({@damage 3d8 + 10})重击、穿刺或砍击伤害（由帝王选择）。

action.name: Divine Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 13}击中，范围300英尺，一个目标。{@h}24 ({@damage 7d6})以下类型的伤害（由帝王选择）：酸，冷，火，力量，闪电，辐射，或雷霆。

action.name: Change Size
entries: 帝释天会神奇地多态化为一个中型或大型的人形物体。帝释天保留了与它的真实形态相同的外观。帝王的神圣武器在小尺寸的情况下伤害会降低。大尺寸的伤害为19({@dice 2d8 + 10})，14({@dice 1d8}
+ 10）为中等大小。除了体型和圣器之外，它的统计数据保持不变。

legendary.name: Attack
entries: 帝国者进行一次攻击。

legendary.name: Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: 帝王会从其神域列表中施放一个二级或更低级的法术。
帝王是被更伟大的神灵万神殿提升为神的凡人。他们通常是神和凡人的后代，他们通过伟大的行为证明自己有资格获得神力。一旦变身，他们就会成为天人，并具有其神域的属性。
力求伟大。帝释天在神殿中处于最低层。他们更多地参与到凡人世界中，以便从更强大的神那里赢得荣耀和关注。他们经常以人类的体型走在凡人中间，以了解这个世界的发展情况。偶尔，他们也会插手凡人的事务。例如，他们可能会鼓励王国之间的战争，将强大的魔法知识引入原始文化，甚至释放强大的怪物，而这些怪物最好保持睡眠状态。
雏形万神殿。有些时候，凡人会努力靠自己去发现神性的秘密。当凡人与他们那个时代的其他伟人结盟时，他们有时能够做到这一点。一个世界的其他万神殿很少欢迎这样的新人，因为多元宇宙中有许多新万神殿取代旧万神殿的故事。随之而来的新神和旧神之间的斗争往往会使一个世界分崩离析。
神圣的领域
每个帝王必须有一个神域，这决定了它可以施展的法术。
死亡之域
- 一级法术：Bane, ray of sickness
- 2级法术：失明/失聪、射线伤害
- 3级法术：赐予诅咒、吸血鬼之触
- 4级法术：枯萎、幻影杀手
- 5级法术：云杀、传染
- 6级法术：伤害
- 七级法术：复活
知识领域
- 一级法术：指挥，引导弹射
- 2级法术：定位物体，暗示
- 3级法术：护身符，与死者对话
• 4th level spells: arcane eye, confusion
• 5th level spells: geas, scrying
• 6th level spells: find the path
• 7th level spells: symbol
Domain of Life
• 1st level spells: cure wounds, bless
• 2nd level spells: aid, spiritual weapon
• 3rd level spells: beacon of hope, mass healing word
• 4th level spells: death ward
• 5th level spells: mass cure wounds, raise dead
• 6th level spells: heal
• 7th level spells: regenerate
Domain of Nature
• 1st level spells: entangle, fog cloud
• 2nd level spells: lesser restoration, spike growth
• 3rd level spells: plant growth, wind wall
• 4th level spells: control water, grasping vine
• 5th level spells: awaken, insect plague

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The empyrean's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 24}, {@hit 15} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast spells from its divine domain, requiring no material components. The empyrean is limited to the following spells:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: 如果帝释天的拯救动作失败，它可以选择成功。

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: 帝释天对法术和其他魔法效果的救赎有优势。

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: 帝王的武器攻击是神奇的。

action.name: Sacred Weapon
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d10 + 10}) bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (empyrean's choice).

action.name: Divine Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 15} to hit, range 300 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 7d6}) damage of one of the following types (empyrean's choice): acid, cold, fire, force, lightning, radiant, or thunder.

action.name: Change Size
entries: The empyrean magically polymorphs into a medium or large-sized humanoid. The empyrean retains the same appearance that it did in its true form. The empyrean's sacred weapon does reduced damage in smaller sizes. 21 ({@dice 2d20 + 10}) for large size and 15 ({@dice 1d10 + 10}) for medium size. Other than its size and sacred weapon, its statistics remain the same.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: 帝国者进行一次攻击。

legendary.name: Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The empyrean casts one spell of 3rd or lower level from its divine domain list.
帝王是被更伟大的神灵万神殿提升为神的凡人。他们通常是神和凡人的后代，他们通过伟大的行为证明自己有资格获得神力。一旦变身，他们就会成为天人，并具有其神域的属性。
力求伟大。帝释天在神殿中处于最低层。他们更多地参与到凡人世界中，以便从更强大的神那里赢得荣耀和关注。他们经常以人类的体型走在凡人中间，以了解这个世界的发展情况。偶尔，他们也会插手凡人的事务。例如，他们可能会鼓励王国之间的战争，将强大的魔法知识引入原始文化，甚至释放强大的怪物，而这些怪物最好保持睡眠状态。
雏形万神殿。有些时候，凡人会努力靠自己去发现神性的秘密。当凡人与他们那个时代的其他伟人结盟时，他们有时能够做到这一点。一个世界的其他万神殿很少欢迎这样的新人，因为多元宇宙中有许多新万神殿取代旧万神殿的故事。随之而来的新神和旧神之间的斗争往往会使一个世界分崩离析。
神圣的领域
每个帝王必须有一个神域，这决定了它可以施展的法术。
死亡之域
- 一级法术：Bane, ray of sickness
- 2级法术：失明/失聪、射线伤害
- 3级法术：赐予诅咒、吸血鬼之触
- 4级法术：枯萎、幻影杀手

- 6级法术：伤害
- 七级法术：复活

- 2级法术：定位物体，暗示

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the gigantes can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Martial Advantage
entries: Once per turn, the gigantes can deal an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage to a creature it hits with a weapon attack if that creature is within 5 feet of an ally of the gigantes that isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gigantes makes three spear attacks or one spit attack.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage, or 14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}38 ({@damage 10d6 + 3}) poison damage plus the target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 10 rounds.

Twisted in body and mind, the hideous gigantes would be a pitiable form of giant were it not for their prodigious cruelty and bloodlust. Gigantes feel driven to kill any intelligent creature they encounter, with the exception of other gigantes—though their violent and unhinged nature means that even minor disagreements between gigantes usually end in bloodshed. Despite these flaws, gigantes are far from dumb brutes, and the average gigantes is as intelligent as the average human. This, combined with their great strength and erratic, unpredictable behavior, makes the gigantes a particularly dangerous foe.

Abandoned Creations. The gigantes were originally created by the Titan Hergeron. He intended them to be his masterpiece, but they were left unfinished when Hergeron was imprisoned by his brother, Sydon. Had the gigantes been completed, it is said that their power would have been the greatest of all the giants. A legend told among the gigantes asserts that if Hergeron is ever freed, he will finish his great work and transform all the gigantes tribes into the perfect warriors.

Corrupted Blood. One of the derangements of the gigantes is that their blood and saliva is poisonous to most other creatures. Thus the gigantes lick their spears before going into battle. They are also known to spit their poison at their enemies. Gigantes witches are able to use this spit to incite bloodlust in gigantes warriors.

Perpetual War. Gigantes are hostile to all other races. They are self-destructive with little regard for even their own lives, and once a gigantes picks a fight it almost always battles to the death. Occasionally, gigantes tribes will work with minotaurs, as they feel some kinship to the cursed bull-headed humanoids.

Social Structure. Although gigantes form social groups, these bands can hardly be called a "community." Each loosely structured group is held together by two or three gigantes witches that claim to draw power from their sleeping god, Hergeron. Gigantes usually dwell in crudely built forts, often constructed in deep forests or high mountains. In Thylea, the most powerful gigantes tribes have been drawn to the lands surrounding the city of Aresia, making travel to and from the city an often deadly task.
Variant: Gigantes Witch

Gigantes witches have the same statistics as regular gigantes, but with the following additions: Incite Rage. As a bonus action, a gigantes witch can spit in a 20 ft. cone. The gigantes witch and any other gigantes in the cone goes into a blood rage for 1 minute. During this time, a gigantes is immune to the charm and frightened conditions. If a gigantes is already charmed or frightened, the condition immediately ends. The gigantes gains advantage on all melee attacks and has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

Innate Spellcasting. The gigantes witch's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 14, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The witch can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
At will: hellish rebuke (at 5th level), mage armor
3/day each: counterspell, spirit guardians (at 5th level)
1/day: destructive wave

trait.name: Petrifying Gaze
entries: When a creature that can see the medusa's eyes starts its turn within 30 feet of the medusa, the medusa can force it to make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw if the medusa can see the creature. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is instantly {@condition petrified}. Otherwise, a creature that fails the save begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} on a failure or ending the effect on a success.
The petrification lasts until the creature is freed by the greater restoration spell or other magic.

Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the medusa until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the medusa in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.
If the medusa sees itself reflected on a polished surface within 30 feet of it and in an area of bright light, the medusa is, due to its curse, affected by its own gaze.

trait.name: Sneak Attack
entries: If the medusa has advantage on a target of a melee attack and it is attacking from stealth, the target cannot cover their eyes and is affected by petrifying gaze.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The medusa makes either two melee attacks with its snake hair and one with its constrict or three ranged attacks with its longbow.

action.name: Snake Hair
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) piercing damage plus 21 ({@damage 6d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Constrict
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the medusa can't constrict another target.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range
150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

Euryale is an ancient medusa that has transformed over millennia into something far more dangerous. With the body of a snake and the strength of a giant, the euryale is rightly feared more than any common medusa.

Ancient Medusa. To become a euryale, a medusa must avoid death for thousands of years. Moreover, they must never catch a glimpse of their own cursed reflection. Like many monstrous magical creatures, medusae become more formidable with age, as they gain in both raw power and the wisdom to master that power. The ability to outthink and outmaneuver countless foes over centuries is also a testament to their cleverness, making the medusa more likely to gain the cooperation of a fiendish patron who can magnify their strengths even further.

Corrupted Beauty. More monstrous than other medusae, a euryale's human aspects have almost entirely vanished. Its previous, weak humanoid body has been replaced with a massive snake-like torso, and its muscular, scaly arms possess strength rivaling a hill giant. The euryale's serpentine body can encircle and crush smaller creatures with ease. Barbed, venomous quills line the bodies of some euryales, and these quills can be detached and used as arrows to strike at foes that stand out of reach. Despite this grotesque bodily transformation, the euryale's face continues to be eternally young and beautiful, if somewhat unsettling. This ensures that the terms of the pact or "boon" that created the original medusa remains unbroken.

Fiendish Pact. Time alone is not enough to transform a medusa into a Euryale. Those that wish to gain greater power must seek out a mighty malevolent entity, such as a demon lord or archdevil. The medusa may agree to perform specific tasks or pledge servitude to such a creature in exchange for its magic. In other cases, capricious beings may transform the medusa for no better reason than their own amusement, hoping to unleash chaos upon the Material Plane. The rare euryale that does not consent to this change often goes mad, leaving its lair to seek vengeance upon whichever unfortunate souls it happens to encounter.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the minotaur moves at least 10 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 ft. away and knocked {@condition prone}. The minotaur can then use a bonus action to attack twice with its greataxe.

trait.name: Labyrinthine Recall
entries: The minotaur can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the minotaur can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The minotaur makes two melee attacks with its greataxe.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

Minotaurs are hulking creatures that look like half-human, half-bull monstrosities. While many minotaurs conform to the classic image of a bull's head atop a human body, others appear much more like humans, distinguished primarily by their immense size and bull-like horns. In spite of this, many mortals treat them as little more than bipedal beasts of burden.

Cursed. Minotaurs are the descendants of a cursed tribe of humans who angered the gods. They are often shunned by the other mortal races, living on the outskirts of civilization in small nomadic tribes.

Shapechangers. Some minotaurs are born with the ability to shapeshift fully into bulls. This transformation is triggered by extreme anger or stress. Minotaurs who make their living as warriors eventually master this transformation and learn to control it.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the minotaur moves at least 10 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 18 ({@damage 4d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 ft. away and knocked {@condition prone}. The minotaur can then use a bonus action to attack twice with its greataxe (humanoid form) or hooves (bull form).

trait.name: Labyrinthine Recall
entries: The minotaur can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the minotaur can gain advantage on all melee weapon Attack rolls it makes during that turn, but Attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The minotaur can use a bonus action to polymorph into a bull, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, other than its AC, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: In humanoid form, the minotaur makes three melee attacks with its battle axes. In bull form, the minotaur makes two attacks with its hooves and one with its gore.

action.name: Battle Axe (humanoid form only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Hooves (bull form only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage.

Minotaurs are hulking creatures that look like half-human, half-bull monstrosities. While many minotaurs conform to the classic image of a bull's head atop a human body, others appear much more like humans, distinguished primarily by their immense size and bull-like horns. In spite of this, many mortals treat them as little more than bipedal beasts of burden.

Cursed. Minotaurs are the descendants of a cursed tribe of humans who angered the gods. They are often shunned by the other mortal races, living on the outskirts of civilization in small nomadic tribes.

Shapechangers. Some minotaurs are born with the ability to shapeshift fully into bulls. This transformation is triggered by extreme anger or stress. Minotaurs who make their living as warriors eventually master this transformation and learn to control it.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The myrmekes can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell that they are imitations with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom (Insight) check.

trait.name: Hive Mind
entries: The myrmekes is in constant telepathic communication with all myrmekes witinin a mile.

Everything a myrmekes learns, all myrmekes in telepathic range learn as well. The myrmekes has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if another myrmekes is within 5 feet of the creature and the myrmekes isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Hive Learning
entries: A myrmekes can learn an action or a trait by watching a humanoid creature use it once. This action or trait can be an arcane spell that is either a cantrip or

1st level and cannot have a material component. Hive learning can also be used to learn the following: bardic inspiration, cunning action, evasion, martial advantage, multiattack, reckless, sneak attack. If it sees any of the following fighting styles being used it can learn them: archery, dueling, two weapon fighting. If it sees a humanoid using extra attacks, it also learns multiattack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

The myrmekes are a tenacious insect-like race that resemble gigantic humanoid ants with shiny black carapaces and beautiful, multicolored wings. A single myrmekes is small and poses little threat. They are made dangerous by their vast numbers: adventurers are very unlikely to encounter just one or two myrmekes. As eusocial beings with a shared hive-mind intelligence, myrmekes maintain constant telepathic communication with all nearby fellows. This creates a network that can respond to distress calls across an expansive territory controlled by the myrmekes. Although not inherently malevolent, myrmekes are a significant threat to all other forms of life in any ecosystem they enter. Their industrious nature, instinct for aggressive expansion, rapacious consumption of resources, and rapid breeding makes the myrmekes incompatible with other creatures. Consequently, the gods imprisoned the myrmekes on a remote island not long after their creation. In addition to the physical barriers surrounding them, the myrmekes are also bound by powerful magic to ensure their eternal isolation. However, if this enchantment was ever broken, these creatures could swarm over every continent, remaking the entire world as an insectoid empire.

Myrmekes Worker. Most myrmekes belong to the worker caste. This subtype is unremarkable, but because of their shared hive mind, even the lowliest drone has a direct link to the queen and access to her unfathomable intelligence. This allows myrmekes to mimic the abilities and traits of other creatures after observing them just once. Additionally, though they lack creativity, this gives myrmekes workers a genius-level intelligence rivaling that of even the most gifted humans.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The myrmekes innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}). The myrmekes can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The myrmekes can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom (Insight) check.

trait.name: Hive Mind
entries: The myrmekes is in constant telepathic communication with all myrmekes witinin a mile. Everything a myrmekes learns, all myrmekes in telepathic range learn as well. The myrmekes has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if another myrmekes is within 5 feet of the creature and the myrmekes isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Hive Learning
entries: A myrmekes can learn an action or a trait by watching a humanoid creature use it once. This action or trait can be an arcane spell that is either a cantrip or level 1 and cannot have a material component. Hive learning can also be use to learn following: bardic inspiration, cunning action, evasion, martial advantage, multiattack, reckless, sneak attack. If it sees any of the following fighting styles being used it can learn them: archery, dueling, two weapon fighting. If it sees a humanoid using extra attacks, it also learns multiattack.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the myrmekes can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Martial Advantage
entries: Once per turn, the myrmekes can deal an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) damage to a creature it hits with a weapon attack if that creature is within 5 feet of an ally of the myrmekes that isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The myrmekes makes two spear attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Ray of Frost
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage. The target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of the myrmekes's next turn.

reaction.name: Shield (1/Day)
entries: The myrmekes casts the shield spell and adds 5 to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the myrmekes must see the attacker.

Consequently, the gods imprisoned the myrmekes on a remote island not long after their creation. In addition to the physical barriers surrounding them, the myrmekes are also bound by powerful magic to ensure their eternal isolation. However, if this enchantment was ever broken, these creatures could swarm over every continent, remaking the entire world as an insectoid empire.

Myrmekes Advanced. Myrmekes that come into contact with other intelligent civilizations assimilate the knowledge and that culture which the myrmekes hive mind deems valuable to its own continued survival. The results of this process are embodied by the myrmekes advanced. These creatures are more skilled than the workers and wield advanced magic. They can use newfound knowledge to fight with weapons and supplement their naturally tough exoskeletons with metal armor.

trait.name: Hive Mind
entries: The myrmekes is in constant telepathic communication with all myrmekes witinin a mile. Everything a myrmekes learns, all myrmekes in telepathic range learn as well. The myrmekes has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if another myrmekes is within 5 feet of the creature and the myrmekes isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Quick Mind
entries: The myrmekes queen can make one reaction for every turn in combat.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The myrmekes queen makes two spit attacks.

action.name: Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 5d8}) acid damage.

reaction.name: Redirect Attack
entries: When a creature the myrmekes queen can see targets it with an attack or spell, the queen chooses another myrmekes within 10 feet of it. The chosen myrmekes becomes the new target.

The myrmekes are a tenacious insect-like race that resemble gigantic humanoid ants with shiny black carapaces and beautiful, multicolored wings. A single myrmekes is small and poses little threat. They are made dangerous by their vast numbers: adventurers are very unlikely to encounter just one or two myrmekes. As eusocial beings with a shared hive-mind intelligence, myrmekes maintain constant telepathic communication with all nearby fellows. This creates a network that can respond to distress calls across an expansive territory controlled by the myrmekes. Although not inherently malevolent, myrmekes are a significant threat to all other forms of life in any ecosystem they enter. Their industrious nature, instinct for aggressive expansion, rapacious consumption of resources, and rapid breeding makes the myrmekes incompatible with other creatures. Consequently, the gods imprisoned the myrmekes on a remote island not long after their creation. In addition to the physical barriers surrounding them, the myrmekes are also bound by powerful magic to ensure their eternal isolation. However, if this enchantment was ever broken, these creatures could swarm over every continent, remaking the entire world as an insectoid empire.

Myrmekes Queen. The queen is the central hub of the swarm's hive mind. She also serves as the mother to all myrmekes, laying countless eggs each day. Despite her larger size and superior intellect, the myrmekes queen is physically weak and extremely vulnerable to attack if caught alone. In fact, it is her great size that makes her too slow to effectively use mimicry, cast spells, or avoid incoming attacks. In the unlikely event that enemies breach her royal chamber, she relies on her subjects to defend her. However, because the myrmekes have never lost a queen to sudden death or assassination, it is uncertain how a violent end for the queen would affect myrmekes civilization. Her loss might disrupt the hive mind completely.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the boar fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the boar moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the boar takes 15 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead. The boar may use its Chaos Presence as a reaction when Relentless is triggered.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Chaos Presence
entries: Each creature of the boar's choice that is within 40 feet of the boar and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or come under the effects of the confusion spell for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to this ability for the next 24 hours.

Mythic beasts are animals that carry a divine spark. These celestial creatures are neither good nor evil and while they are not unique, mortals rarely catch a glimpse of even one mythic beast in their lifetimes. The elusive beasts make their homes in the great forests and plains of both the fey and mortal realms. They are highly intelligent creatures that have the ability to speak. There are four mythic beasts spoken of in legends: the golden lion, the white stag, the great boar, and the golden ram.
Great Boar

With its monstrous size and many fearsome tusks, there is no mistaking the great boar for an earthly creature. Great boar hunts are often organized to procure a grand sacrifice to the gods, though sometimes they are undertaken for the fame of slaying such a hugely fearsome creature. The great boar is dangerous for its amazing strength and deadly tusks, and because it brings madness to its foes. All but the most disciplined parties fall prey to this madness, and many hunters have died at the hands of their fellows.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The stag's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 13}). The stag can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
footerEntries: 1/year: wish (It can only benefit others with this spell. It will only do this if captured or reduced below 20 HP.)

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the stag fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the stag moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the stag can make one hooves attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The stag has advantage on saving throws agasint spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

Mythic beasts are animals that carry a divine spark. These celestial creatures are neither good nor evil and while they are not unique, mortals rarely catch a glimpse of even one mythic beast in their lifetimes. The elusive beasts make their homes in the great forests and plains of both the fey and mortal realms. They are highly intelligent creatures that have the ability to speak. There are four mythic beasts spoken of in legends: the golden lion, the white stag, the great boar, and the golden ram.
White Stag

Running through forests on its bronze hooves is the white stag. Although not as physically imposing as the other mythic beasts, the unparalleled speed of the white stag make it a challenge to hunters. Despite its pure white fur, the stag can blend in perfectly with any shadows to evade even the most observant mortals. Hunting the white stag often represents a spiritual quest, and legends say that those who can catch the beast without killing it will be granted their greatest desire.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the lion fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The lion has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The lion's bite and claw attacks are considered magical

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the lion moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the lion can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the lion can jump up to 50 feet in a straight line.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) piercing damage. The lion's bite always does maximum damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) slashing damage. The lion's claws always do maximum damage.

Mythic beasts are animals that carry a divine spark. These celestial creatures are neither good nor evil and while they are not unique, mortals rarely catch a glimpse of even one mythic beast in their lifetimes. The elusive beasts make their homes in the great forests and plains of both the fey and mortal realms. They are highly intelligent creatures that have the ability to speak. There are four mythic beasts spoken of in legends: the golden lion, the white stag, the great boar, and the golden ram.
Golden Lion

The golden lion is an enormous, solitary hunter that does not have a pride like its mundane kin. Its golden fur is as strong as steel, providing the lion with tough natural armor that is immune to non-magical weapons. Some report that only the golden lion's own teeth and claws, which are sharper than any mortal weapon, can cut through its hide. Because of this legendary resilience, a golden lion's pelt is highly prized as a material for forging powerful magic items.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ram's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). The ram can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the ram fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the ram moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Blinding Fleece
entries: In sunlight, the golden fleece of the ram gives it the benefits of the blur spell. Anyone attacking the golden ram must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for one day.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

Mythic beasts are animals that carry a divine spark. These celestial creatures are neither good nor evil and while they are not unique, mortals rarely catch a glimpse of even one mythic beast in their lifetimes. The elusive beasts make their homes in the great forests and plains of both the fey and mortal realms. They are highly intelligent creatures that have the ability to speak. There are four mythic beasts spoken of in legends: the golden lion, the white stag, the great boar, and the golden ram.
Golden Ram

The most obviously "celestial" of the mythic beasts, the golden ram can traverse any terrain and can even run through the sky itself. They also possess innate healing magic and are said to be able to raise the dead. Like the golden lion's fur, the ram's brilliant golden fleece is a much sought-after component for magic items. Unlike the lion, however, the ram can be shorn, so it is not necessary to kill a golden ram to obtain its fleece. Instead, adventurers may choose to bargain with a golden ram or convince it of their great and worthy need for its fleece.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The aurae has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Fey Beauty
entries: When a creature that can see the aurae starts its turn within 40 ft. of the aurae, the aurae can force it to make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. Failure means that the creature is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Fey Songs
entries: The aurae can sing a magical song. Creatures with less than 12 Charisma have disadvantage on saving throws against these songs.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The aurae sings one song and uses her kiss.

action.name: Kiss of Obsession
entries: The aurae kisses a {@condition charmed} target within 5 feet. The target must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become obsessed with the aurae. The target will defend her to the death against any of her enemies, even if those enemies are friends. A creature can make another saving throw at the end of its turn to end the effect, but only if it has taken damage that turn.

action.name: Song of Charming
entries: Every creature within 300 feet of the aurae that can hear the song must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the song ends. While {@condition charmed} by the aurae, a creature is {@condition incapacitated}. The {@condition charmed} creature must move towards the aurae using its full move and the most direct route without moving into damaging terrain. A {@condition charmed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns with a success ending the song's effect on it.

action.name: Song of Discord
entries: Every creature within 300 feet of the aurae that can hear the song takes 1 psychic damage from a splitting headache. A creature under the slumber effect of the aurae takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage from violent nightmares. This damage does not wake the creature.

action.name: Song of Slumber
entries: Every creature within 10 feet of the aurae that can hear the song must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. A failure results in the creature falling asleep. The creature can only be awoken if it takes at least 10 damage or half of its hit points, whichever is less.
NYMPHS

Nymphs are powerful fey who embody the splendor of the natural world. Architects of wild beauty, nymphs are bound to, and protect, the forests, rivers, springs, meadows, mountains, and seas they shape and call home. Nymphs feel a greater kinship to elves than do most other fey, and the two groups resemble each other in general appearance, though nymphs have more obviously supernatural features.

Enigmatic Values. All nymphs are incredibly beautiful and demand to be surrounded by aesthetically elegant creatures and items that rival their own appearance. They are chaotic beings that believe in the importance of beauty above all else. Rather than viewing the world in terms of good and evil, most nymphs see only beauty and ugliness. To them, actions that create beauty are laudable; beautiful creatures and objects must be protected. That which destroys or damages beauty, or promotes ugliness, must be eradicated.

Secluded Surroundings. Nymphs make homes in the most beautiful locations of the natural world. They augment these places, nurturing the plants, shaping the earth, and purifying the water. Those seeking a nymph should look to the most breathtaking natural landmarks in their vicinity as a sign of her presence. However, intruders are rarely welcome, as most nymphs prefer to live in solitude. Many nymph homes lie on the borders between the fey and the mortal realm. Time passes differently in these locations, and mortals who unwittingly wander into a nymph's domain for an afternoon may find themselves displaced by centuries in time.

Ephemeral Lovers. Many prominent heroes of legend are thought to be the offspring of nymphs. Affairs between nymphs and mortals tend to be fleeting and frequently end in tragedy. Powerful mortals who are seduced into joining nymphs in the fey realm may disappear from the mortal realm for centuries, throwing kingdoms into chaos in the meantime. Nymphs taken into the mortal world as wives and husbands soon pine for the natural splendor of their wild homes, and they usually abandon their mortal families.
Types of Nymphs
Nymphs are divided into six subraces: dryads of the forests, naiads of lakes and rivers, nereids of the oceans, oreads of the mountains, oceanids of the islands, and aurae of the night sky.
Nymphs may be male, female, both, or neither. However, most nymphs possess certain delicate feminine qualities, regardless of their gender, and they are collectively described with feminine pronouns.
Nymph Lairs

The lair of a nymph is a beautiful, natural place that reflects her type. For example, dryads make their lairs in the branches and roots of a great tree to which she is bound. Naiads often dwell within underwater caves that can only be reached by swimming beneath a river or lake. Oreads may choose picturesque ruins located high in the mountain that she calls home. When a nymph's lair contains a connection to the fey, or lies within the fey, she gains access to lair actions.
Lair Actions
On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the nymph can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects:
• The nymph glimpses the future, so that it has advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until initiative count 20 on the next round.

• The nymph merges with her surroundings and reappears anywhere in her lair. This ability functions exactly like dimension door except that it requires no components and the range is limited to within the nymph's lair.
Regional Effects
The region containing a nymph's lair is warped by the ephemeral nature of the feywild.
• Time passes differently in the lair of the nymph. Every day spent there counts as a month in the mortal world. The nymph can decrease this rate of time passage to a week or increase it to a year.
• Monstrosities, aberrations, fiends, and humanoids with Charisma scores of 8 or less feel extremely uncomfortable in a nymph's lair. They have disadvantage on all saving throws and ability checks.
Aurae

Aurea are nymphs associated with the sea and the night sky, currents, breezes, and the constellations. Each aurae claims an island for her home, and she guards it with fearsome devotion. The most territorial of the nymphs, aurae have taken it upon themselves to stem the tide of civilization and do not tolerate mortals on their islands. They are not malicious or cruel, and they always give trespassers fair warning to leave. But if their words go unheeded, they will not hesitate to smite interlopers with all their power.

Aurae sometimes become muses for mortals. These nymphs have an innate fascination with words and language, and thrill in the abilities of poets, storytellers, and lyricists. Some of history's greatest songs, poems, and tales are thought to have been inspired by aurae.

Like other nymphs, aurae can charm others to fight for them, but they also wield great strength, both physical and magical. In battle, aurae weave fey magic into beautiful songs to lull their opponents to sleep and to inflict psychic harm through vivid nightmares.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The naiad's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}). The naiad can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The naiad has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Fey Beauty
entries: When a creature that can see the naiad starts its turn within 40 ft. of the naiad, the naiad can force it to make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. Failure means that the creature is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2})

action.name: Fey Allure
entries: The naiad targets one humanoid it can see within 30 ft. of it. If the target can see the nymph, the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw against this magic or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. Creatures with less than 12 Charisma have disadvantage on these saving throws.

• Time passes differently in the lair of the nymph. Every day spent there counts as a month in the mortal world. The nymph can decrease this rate of time passage to a week or increase it to a year.
• Monstrosities, aberrations, fiends, and humanoids with Charisma scores of 8 or less feel extremely uncomfortable in a nymph's lair. They have disadvantage on all saving throws and ability checks.
Naiad
Nymphs of fresh water, naiads make their homes in lakes, streams, brooks, and wetlands. Naiads are the nymphs that are most likely to come into contact with mortals.

Humans need to be close to reliable sources of fresh water, and this frequently creates an overlap between the domains of mortals and naiads. Some naiads even choose to live in man-made structures, such as fountains and wells, if they deem them beautiful enough to call home. Although naiads are often very curious about the mortal world, their patience for the ugly noise and bustle of cities remains short.

Naiads are coveted by mortals for both their great beauty and their talents. They often have the ability to divine the fate of mortals. They have been known to use this power to shape history, as mysterious oracles and advisors. Naiads also serve as muses to great artists and musicians, taking them to a level of creativity that only supernatural assistance can inspire. Thanks to these abilities, powerful mortals frequently fall in love with naiads, and they are the most likely of all nymphs to give birth to mortal children with grand destinies.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The nereid's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). The nereid can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The nereid can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The nereid has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Song of Battle
entries: As a bonus action, the nereid can sing a song that gives advantage to one target creature on the next action that it performs.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The nereid makes three attacks with her trident.

action.name: Trident
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) electrical damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) electrical damage if used with two hands.

• Monstrosities, aberrations, fiends, and humanoids with Charisma scores of 8 or less feel extremely uncomfortable in a nymph's lair. They have disadvantage on all saving throws and ability checks.
Nereid

Nereids are beautiful female fey that dwell beneath the ocean waves. There, they fiercely defend coral reefs and all natural life that dwell within it. Although quick swimmers in their own right, nereids often seek the aid of dolphin or seahorse mounts to bolster their effectiveness in battle. Nereids are as attached to such creatures as paladins are to their steeds; should the animal fall in battle, its rider may be overcome by grief. Each nereid wields her own personal trident, which is grown from the same coral they protect. Although they are dangerous when threatened, nereid sightings are considered to be a portent of good luck for sailors. Wise captains know to steer clear of their reefs, so as to avoid damaging them with the ship's anchor. In addition to their skill as warriors, nereids are also well known for their exquisite voices, which can travel through water undistorted. Unlike the songs of many other aquatic fey, nereids do not weave enchantments into their music; they sing for beauty's sake.

Benthic Beauties. Nereids are sometimes mistaken for merfolk at first glance. They possess streamlined, slightly alien features that are as striking as they are beautiful. Diaphanous webbing connects the fingers and toes of a nereid, and their slick skin resembles that of a dolphin, albeit in various shades of blue and green. Some nereids have additional fish-like traits, such as visible gills and fins that run along their limbs and back, though this aspect of their anatomy is highly variable, depending on their tribe.

Guiding the Lost. Many nereids display a level of benevolence towards humanoids that is rare among fey. Nereids have been known to shepherd lost sailors safely back to civilization, provided that they show adequate respect for nature. Some nereids even establish long-term relationships with the sailors who frequent their waters, steering their ships away from the sea's many hidden dangers.

Defenders of Reefs. Nereids are bound to protect a specific coral reef, just as dryads are bound to their forests. Overtly hostile nereids are rare, and they usually do not discourage the intrusion of mortals into their domains. However, visitors should be wary to not mistake their relatively kind natures for softness; should their homes be at all harmed or threatened, nereids retaliate en-masse with a piranha-like tenacity, giving no quarter to their prey.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The oceanid's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}). The oceanid can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The oceanid can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The oceanid has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Trickery
entries: While the oceanid is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, his AC includes his Charisma modifier. A combination of light, illusion, sound and unpredictable movement are part of this effect, thus true seeing does not negate it.

trait.name: Move Through the Wind and Currents
entries: As a bonus action, the oceanid can move up to 60 ft. The oceanid can move through spaces occupied by enemies with this movement. Any enemy that it moves through must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The oceanid makes two attacks with his dagger.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d4 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage.

Nymphs taken into the mortal world as wives and husbands soon pine for the natural splendor of their wild homes, and they usually abandon their mortal families.
Types of Nymphs
Nymphs are divided into six subraces: dryads of the forests, naiads of lakes and rivers, nereids of the oceans, oreads of the mountains, oceanids of the islands, and aurae of the night sky.
Nymphs may be male, female, both, or neither. However, most nymphs possess certain delicate feminine qualities, regardless of their gender, and they are collectively described with feminine pronouns.
Nymph Lairs

The lair of a nymph is a beautiful, natural place that reflects her type. For example, dryads make their lairs in the branches and roots of a great tree to which she is bound. Naiads often dwell within underwater caves that can only be reached by swimming beneath a river or lake. Oreads may choose picturesque ruins located high in the mountain that she calls home. When a nymph's lair contains a connection to the fey, or lies within the fey, she gains access to lair actions.
Lair Actions
On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the nymph can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects:
• The nymph glimpses the future, so that it has advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until initiative count 20 on the next round.

• The nymph merges with her surroundings and reappears anywhere in her lair. This ability functions exactly like dimension door except that it requires no components and the range is limited to within the nymph's lair.
Regional Effects
The region containing a nymph's lair is warped by the ephemeral nature of the feywild.
• Time passes differently in the lair of the nymph. Every day spent there counts as a month in the mortal world. The nymph can decrease this rate of time passage to a week or increase it to a year.
• Monstrosities, aberrations, fiends, and humanoids with Charisma scores of 8 or less feel extremely uncomfortable in a nymph's lair. They have disadvantage on all saving throws and ability checks.
Oceanid

Oceanids are a type of fey who travel the coasts, often bringing music and merriment in their wake. They are most well known for their fascination with humanoids and largely take on forms that mimic handsome male members of these races. Oceanids adore beauty of all kinds but personally lack subtlety. They are invariably flashy, dressing in brightly-colored clothing and heavily adorning themselves in jewelry.

Mutable Shapes. Oceanids are shapeshifters who typically take forms that are almost physically indistinguishable from male humanoids. An oceanid rarely assumes a single guise for more than a month or two at a time, but he may revisit an identity later on. Many bear minor tells that go largely unnoticed, such as too-green eyes or sweat that smells too closely of ocean brine. Though they may lack "true forms," oceanids sometimes also appear as creatures akin to water elementals, albeit in a closer approximation of human shape.

Tricksters of the Shore. Oceanids spend much of their time tricking and playing pranks upon mortals. These tricks are usually harmless, but they can be infuriating. A common example of an oceanid prank is to exchange jewelry for other valuable trinkets—items that soon crumble into sand once the oceanid takes his leave. However, some oceanid pranks can turn fatal, often in the form of drownings. In another favorite oceanid prank, the oceanid lures his target into dangerous currents with illusory calm waters. Although some oceanids are indeed malicious, any deaths resulting from their pranks are usually unintentional. Oceanids can be poor judges of mortal swimming ability and lead victims to their dooms in their ignorance. When such a fate befalls an object of an oceanid's affections, he may become so overcome with grief that he dissolves into seafoam.

Consummate Musicians. Like many fey creatures, oceanids have a fondness for music and are skilled players of lutes, lyres, and other stringed instruments. Many oceanids delight in sharing their expertise with humanoids, and their pupils often go on to become famous bards. Although not always a means of enchantment, some oceanids use their songs to magically attract mortals to the shore. Such lures are often necessary, as oceanids begin to lose their mental faculties if they stray too far inland. However, their intentions for doing so vary: one oceanid may simply want an audience, while another may seek to draw in new victims for his pranks.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The ichthys can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ichthys has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Deep Ocean Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the ichthys to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken (unless the damage is a critical hit). On a success, the ichthys drops to 1 hit point instead and enters a rage for 1 minute. While raging, the ichthys has advantage on all attacks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ichthys makes two attacks with his trident and two attacks with his claws.

action.name: Trident
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, or 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition grappled} if it is medium sized or smaller (escape
{@dc 15}). The ichthys has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

With an appearance that treads the line between the comedic and horrific, the ichthys is a twisted centaur-like creature with a humanoid upper body that protrudes from the shell of a massive crab. This monster is the result of a cruel curse bestowed by the gods upon merfolk and other aquatic humanoids, usually as punishment for severe transgressions. As a result of their loathsome origins, most merfolk look upon ichthyses with utter disgust, and the creatures become outcast from merfolk societies. Doomed to aimlessly wander the seafloor, the ichthys becomes consumed by the desire to search for victims as outlets for its unrelenting pain and anger The only joys it knows are those of torture and senseless bloodshed. Most ichthyses continue to wield the same weapons they did before their transformation. Hence, the creatures tend to favor tridents and other implements used by merfolk.

Tortured Forms. An ichthys's body is racked with perpetual pain, and any attempts at quick movement are especially agonizing. This state is a product of the strain put upon crustacean anatomy that is not designed to support heavy humanoid torsos. Despite its incompatible physiologies, the body of an ichthys continues to function by way of the curse's magic. Pain and poor balance create a plodding, awkward gait paired with a relatively slow swimming speed.

Macabre Artists. Although largely nomadic, ichthyses set up temporary camps on the seafloor. There, an ichthys uses the bodies of its victims as bait to draw the attentions of both food and other humanoids. An ichthys arranges these corpses to create grotesque sculpture gardens. It often begins to "sculpt" its subjects when they are still alive, tying them in place before further carving into their flesh. An ichthys will sometimes leave a victim half dead, as their feeble attempts at escape make for an excellent lure.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Scylla can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Scylla has advantage on saves vs spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: Scylla can take one reaction per turn, rather than one per round.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: Scylla's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Scylla fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Scylla makes three bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) piercing damage + 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d8 + 10}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. Scylla has twelve tentacles, each of which can grapple one target.

action.name: Cacophonous Dirge
entries: One of Scylla's heads sings a song. Each creature within 120 feet of Scylla must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by Scylla until the end of Scylla's next turn. Once the charm effect ends, the creature becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Scylla's dirge for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Scylla makes one tentacle attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Scylla can move up to its speed.

legendary.name: Song
entries: One of Scylla's head sings the dirge.

One of the most grotesque monstrosities to ever roam the sea, Scylla is a gargantuan mass of writhing flesh driven by an endless hunger. Six massive canine heads stretch out on six long, serpentine necks that protrude from her largely featureless body. Each of her heavily scarred heads is equipped with three rows of serrated teeth that point downward, into a throat that is capable of swallowing a horse whole.

Scylla's bulk is supported by a dozen muscular tentacles. Though her limbs are capable of moving her with surprising speed, Scylla prefers to take the role of an ambush predator, lying in wait and reaching out with her maws whenever prey wanders too close. Although Scylla prefers ocean waters, she can move just as easily on land should she ever be motivated to. She spends most of her time in the deepest parts of the ocean.

Insatiable Frenzy. Scylla is able to feel nothing but hunger. Had she any thoughts to communicate, Scylla would nonetheless be incapable of expressing them. She "speaks" only in a cacophonous chorus of mad barks and whines, which is said to drive any who hear it insane.

Birthplace of Monsters. Scylla originates from Typhon, an island whose magical energies birth countless other hybrid abominations, including chimeras and manticores. However, Scylla is Typhon's worst "child" by far, both in form and the amount of damage she wreaks. Some legends claim that Scylla was once a beautiful nymph who was imprisoned on Typhon for countless years. Over time, its corruption slowly twisted her body and mind into the monstrosity she is today. By the time she was strong enough to break free of her bonds, any semblance of the nymph she was had long been replaced by hunger and madness.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The sea serpent can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the sea serpent fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sea serpent makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d10 + 10}) piercing damage. If the target is a large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the sea serpent. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the sea serpent, and it takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the sea serpent's turns.

If the sea serpent takes 50 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the sea serpent must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the sea serpent. If the sea serpent dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 40 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

As its name suggests, the sea serpent is a monstrous snake that makes its home within the ocean waves. Many who face the creature never come close to seeing the end of its tail, as the sea serpent's body reaches hundreds of feet in length. The sea serpent is so large that its back creates the illusion of a chain of islands as it slithers through the waves. Often mistaken as a dragon due to its massive size, the sea serpent is actually descended from gargantuan, primordial snakes.

Although the creature's diet mainly consists of whales and sharks, it is also a major hazard for sailors, as the large size and oblong shape of ships attract its attention. Assuming it has found a feast, the sea serpent wraps its coils around the vessel and squeezes until it becomes a splintered wreck. From there, it proceeds to attempt to swallow the structure whole—unless it is distracted by attacks from the ship's occupants.

Surviving the Serpent. Anyone wishing to fight a sea serpent should make killing the beast one's sole priority. Wounding the monster only makes it redouble its efforts in a fit of rage, and it always fights to the death. In the unlikely event that a creature survives the sea serpent's bite, the creature is nonetheless doomed, as the serpent will inevitably swallow any prey that it catches in its jaws. If swallowed whole, a victim is likely to only live a few minutes before being dissolved by the serpent's powerful stomach acid.

Monster of the Depths. The sea serpent prefers to stay in deep waters. Its massive size makes maneuvering in the shallows difficult and across any appreciable amount of land impossible. Additionally, the creature bears a deep hatred of the sound of thunder and will dive deep to avoid electrical storms.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The cerberus has advantage on saves vs spells and other magical effects.

Three heads. The cerberus has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, or knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The cerberus has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The cerberus makes three bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) piercing damage + 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage, and the creature must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The infernal cerberus makes one attack.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The infernal cerberus makes a Wisdom (Perception) check with advantage.

legendary.name: Bark
entries: The infernal cerberus barks. All other creatures within 60 feet of the infernal cerberus must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} for 1 minute and knocked {@condition prone}.

Sometimes called Gloom Hounds or Hounds of Hades, these three-headed creatures are bred to be the ultimate guardians. Very few creatures can successfully sneak past a cerebus hound that guards a doorway or treasure. Tortured by Hags. Hags train these creatures through abuse designed to instill fear and rage. No hound in their charge is ever shown affection, and they are kept either in total isolation or attached to chains too short to allow the pups to comfort each other. Large groups of cerberus hounds are sometimes given very little food, in order to identify weaker dogs for culling. The hags then sew shut the mouths of the runts and encourage their former packmates to devour them. The hags also present the hounds with captive humanoids, bound and mutilated, in order to give them a taste for blood.

Progenitors of Death Dogs. Cerebus hounds can spawn litters of death dogs. They will only do this if there is enough food to satiate the hunger of all the hounds. The death dogs acknowledge the cerebus as the pack alpha. Whenever a cerebus dies, the death dogs fight for primacy. The victor devours the losers, and over the course of a month, it grows a new head, becoming a new cerebus to replace the original.

Fearsome Guardians. Cerberus hounds take pride in sniffing out and devouring trespassers. Once they have been set to guard something, they never tire of their charge, even should hundreds of years pass without incident. Most hounds keep piles of their victims' bones as beloved trophies to gnaw on. Although the hound does require sleep, it rarely succumbs to the urge, and only one of its heads sleeps at any given time.
Variant: Young Cerberus.

Cerberus hounds that aren't yet fully grown are referred to as young cerberus. They are CR 5 (1,800 XP), cannot use the bark action, and cannot use lair actions. They are Large sized and have Hit Points: 126 (12d10 + 60).
Lair Actions
On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the cerebus hound can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects:

• The cerberus creates the effects of the darkness spell at a point located within 60 feet of it. This magical darkness spreads to a 30-foot radius (rather than 15). This effects ends when the cerberus dismisses it as an action, uses a lair action again, or dies.

• Fire erupts from a chosen point within 60 feet of the cerebus in a 15-foot-radius sphere, until the hound dismisses it as an action, uses a lair action again, or dies. When the fire appears, each creature within its volume must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5d8 fire damage (or half as much on a successful save). A creature must also make this saving throw when it enters the area for the first time or ends its turn there.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the dread boar moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 20 ({@damage 6d6}) damage.
If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Stench
